conclusion: Choose coordinates and list the known facts
Take the dashed blue line (through P and M) as the x-axis (y = 0). Positive x is to the right, positive y is downward, the z-axis points out of the paper.
Above y = 0 there is only a uniform electric field E = –E ĵ (downward).
Between the two vertical baffles (P-Q and M-N, distance l apart) there is only a perpendicular magnetic field B = B k̂ (out of the paper).
The particle starts somewhere on the line y > 0 with initial velocity v⃗₀ = v₀ î (purely horizontal to the right).
It reaches the point P (x = L, y = 0) after travelling through the electric-field region.
When it enters the magnetic field at P the angle between its velocity and the vertical PQ is 60°.
There is no horizontal force, so vₓ = v₀ (constant).
The only acceleration is the electric one, directed downward: a = qE/m (magnitude).
Hence the vertical velocity component at time t is v_y = a t = (qE/m) t.
The horizontal displacement in that time is x = v₀ t.
At P the velocity components are vₓ = v₀ and v_y (downward). The angle φ between the velocity vector and the vertical direction satisfies tan φ = vₓ / v_y.
Given φ = 60°, tan 60° = √3 ⇒ √3 = v₀ / v_y → v_y = v₀ / √3.
From v_y = (qE/m) t and v_y = v₀ / √3: t = m v₀ /(qE √3).
Using x = v₀ t and t = m v₀ /(qE √3): L = v₀ · ( m v₀ /(qE √3) ) = m v₀² /( √3 q E ).

Inside the magnetic region the field B can always be adjusted so that the curved trajectory stays between the plates and leaves through the opening QN; thus no additional condition involving l or B is required for finding L.
The distance from the launch point to point P is L = m v₀² / ( √3 q E ).
